artworkData.intro: Titian’s painting depicts the Greek hero Perseus dramatically diving towards a ferocious sea monster in order to liberate Andromeda, a chained African princess (shown here with gleaming white skin). This painting was much sought after on Europe’s early modern art markets, where it passed through the hands of numerous collectors who profited from enslavement, but also from buying and flipping artworks like this.

provenanceEvents.title: 1. A painting owned by kings and artists
provenanceEvents.text: Titian’s Perseus and Andromeda was painted in the 1550s for Spain’s King Philip II (1527-98) during the so-called “Golden Age” of Spanish art and imperial expansion. This myth of a bound and captive Ethiopian princess (described as Black in some ancient accounts) rescued by a Greek hero resonated strongly with early modern European collectors and artists. Two such artists likely owned this work: the Italian sculptor Leone Leoni, who was himself imprisoned on the papal galleys, and the Flemish painter Anthony Van Dyck, who acquired it in 1623.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Titian, Perseus and Andromeda, 1554-6. Oil on canvas, 183.3 x 199.3 cm. Wallace Collection, London (CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0).
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Titian, Perseus and Andromeda, 1554-6. Oil on canvas, 183.3 x 199.3 cm. Wallace Collection, London (CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0).

provenanceEvents.title: 2. Part of the (in)famous Orléans Collection
provenanceEvents.text:
By 1723, after passing through the hands of several other French collectors, Titian’s painting had joined the Orléans Collection, recognized as perhaps the most significant private collection of Western art.

Assembled in large part by Philippe II, duc d’Orléans (1674-1723), who served as Regent of France from 1715-23—during a period when he and his cronies gained and lost fortunes through colonial speculation—the collection was displayed in the lavish Palais-Royal in Paris.

It was hung alongside other Titian paintings that were collectively known as the artist’s poesie, a series of meditations on Ovid’s Metamorphoses, including this tale of Perseus rescuing the Ethiopian princess Andromeda.

In 1785, the Orléans collection was inherited by the Regent’s great-grandson Louis-Philippe-Joseph, duc de Chartres, who became the duc d’Orléans upon the death of his father that year.

This latest heir to the Orléans art collection was a plantation owner who would later become the pro-Revolution noble known as Philippe Egalité.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Interior of the Galerie Dorée (now the Banque de France), Paris. Photo by Laura C. Jenkins
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Interior of the Galerie Dorée (now the Banque de France), Paris. Photo by Laura C. Jenkins

provenanceEvents.title: 3. Laborde de Méréville’s purchase and sale of the Orléans collection
provenanceEvents.text:
In 1792, Louis Philippe d’Orléans (1787-93), known then as Philippe Egalité, sold part of the Orléans collection to the Brussels banker Édouard de Walckiers.

A close friend of the comte de Vaudreuil (from whom he acquired a sugar plantation in Saint-Domingue/Haiti), Philippe Egalité had dissipated the family fortune through gambling and made a huge profit off the sale.

Very soon after, Walckiers’s cousin, François Laborde de Méréville, who had spent a few years in Saint-Domingue managing his own family’s extensive sugar plantations, bought the collection for nearly a million francs and brought it to London (a move that contributed to his father’s arrest and subsequent execution by guillotine).

He too made a fortune by selling the paintings to Michael Bryan in 1798 for £43,500, the equivalent of 7 million dollars today.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Louis-Joseph Mondhare, Perspective view of the garden façade of the Palais Royal, 1760. Engraving, 27 x 46 cm. Image source: gallica.bnf.fr / Bibliothèque nationale de France.
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Louis-Joseph Mondhare, Perspective view of the garden façade of the Palais Royal, 1760. Engraving, 27 x 46 cm. Image source: gallica.bnf.fr / Bibliothèque nationale de France.

provenanceEvents.title: 4. On the London art market
provenanceEvents.text:
Together with Jeremiah Harman, a director of the Bank of England and an important art collector, Bryan formed a syndicate to sell the paintings, which the British Royal Academy had tried to acquire but couldn’t afford.

More than 300 French, Spanish, and Italian works were publicly exhibited in 1798 in two London venues—Pall Mall and the Lyceum in the Strand—and some were bought by John Angerstein, a major benefactor to London’s National Gallery.

Titian’s painting, however, was sold a few years later and, after passing through various hands on the London art market, it was acquired by the 3rd Marquess of Hertford (1777-1842) for £362.10.

His collection forms part of the Wallace Collection in London, which opened as a museum in 1897.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Joseph Farington, Diagram the Orléans collection displayed at the Lyceum in London in 1799. Getty Research Institute, Los Angeles, 880391.
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Joseph Farington, Diagram the Orléans collection displayed at the Lyceum in London in 1799. Getty Research Institute, Los Angeles, 880391.

nodes.bio: King of Spain (1527–1598). A major patron of Titian's works during the so-called 'Golden Age' of Spanish art and imperial expansion.
Italian sculptor, famously a galley slave, and one of the potential owners of Titian’s Perseus and Andromeda. Based in Milan.
Flemish painter who acquired the painting in 1623. Also based in Milan around that time.
Seigneur de La Vrillière (1598–1681), who purchased the painting around 1655 and displayed it in his 'Galerie Dorée' in Paris.
A French noble and collector. The painting later became part of the Orléans Collection after passing through various hands.
Regent of France (1715–23). Assembled the Orléans Collection, noted for large-scale art patronage and colonial speculation.
Louis-Philippe-Joseph, duc d’Orléans. A plantation owner and pro-Revolution noble who inherited the Orléans Collection in 1785.
A Brussels banker who acquired part of the Orléans Collection from Philippe Egalité in 1792.
Cousin of Édouard de Walckiers; managed sugar plantations in Saint-Domingue and brought the Orléans Collection to London.
An art dealer who purchased the collection from François Laborde de Méréville and formed a syndicate to sell it in London.
Director of the Bank of England and a key art collector. Collaborated with Michael Bryan to sell the Orléans Collection.
Acquired Titian's painting for £362.10. His collection later became part of the Wallace Collection in London.
A major art museum in London, opened in 1897. Houses the Hertford family's art collections, including Titian’s Perseus and Andromeda.
